data.text: Broken Spoke on Rear Wheel when Bicycle Touring

How do you deal with a broken spoke on a rear wheel when on tour? I replace them when at home but for a rear wheel I often need to remove the cassette. Great at home with a chain whip and a cassette tool but how do you deal with this when on tour without have to take these tools? I do know if it breaks in the middle, you can get a small kit to splice it together. However, mine often break at the base (J bend). So how to deal with a broken rear spike on tour? (Photo is not my wheel!)
FiberFix spoke. Got me 600 miles until I could get to a bike shop and have it replaced. Tire didn‚Äôt need trued either.

data.text: Buy a spoke which is LONGER than you need. Cut the lump off the end. Bend it to form a squared off S shape where the nipple was, you feed that through the hub flange hole. Then attach nipple as normal and tighten slowly so the shoulder of the S is held in the flange. Quick and dirty method, which isn't actualy very quick, but it works to get you to civilisation (a bike workshop with tools). If the spoke breaks anywhere except on the shoulder just tape it to the nearest spoke and carry on. Deal with the resulting issues when you reach civilisation. You do carry three spokes with you taped to your pump? Correct sizes for front wheel, rear wheel drive side and non drive side. No? Me neither, but I do have the correct lengths listsed in my book of all knowledge (diary)

data.text: If you keep braking spokes, take the wheel to a reputable bike shop and have them re-build you a wheel with a new rim. You shouldn't need more than 36 spokes if you're using a strong, double-walled rim. I use the VeloCity Cliffhanger on the front and a VeloCity Dyad on the rear. When fully loaded, the bike weighs 150 lbs and I often ride it on rough double track in remote places with no problems whatsoever. Spokes usually fail on road/touring bikes because they're not evenly tensioned. Ideally, each spoke should have the same amount of tension as measured with a tensiometer. When the tension isn't equalized, higher tensioned spokes bear more of the load than lower tensioned spokes and this can cause the rim to want to deflect and becomes exasperated as the load increases. A properly built wheel will have spokes that have the same tension and the right amount of tension on one side of the wheel, either the drive-side for the rear wheel or the non-drive side for a front disc brake wheel. Most people think that a wheel needs to be perfectly true, but a little wobble is okay if the spokes are properly tensioned -- that's much more important. Nevertheless, FiberFix spokes don't take up much space so I always carry two just for peace of mind.

data.text: Prior to travelling, take a slightly longer spoke and snip the head off at the j bend. Bend the end of the spoke (use long nose pliers) so that the original 'tail' of the j is now parallel to the spoke rather than at 90 degrees. This spoke can now be fitted (snaked into the hole from the inner part of the hub) without removing the cassette should you lose a drive side spoke. Simple, cheap and effective...worked for me on multi week tours... then fix properly when you get home :)
